'''Aasif Hakim Mandviwala'''<ref name="tampa">{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/features/media/article545843.ece|title=For Aasif Mandvi, cultural irreverence on 'The Daily Show'|author=Deggans, Eric|publisher=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=June 1, 2008|accessdate=November 7, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081214212553/http://www.tampabay.com/features/media/article545843.ece|archivedate=December 14, 2008|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> (born March 5, 1966), known professionally as '''Aasif Mandvi''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɑː|s|ᵻ|f|_|ˈ|m|ɑː|n|d|v|i}}, {{respell|AH|sif|_|MAHND|vee}}), is a British-American actor and comedian. He began appearing as an occasional contributing correspondent on ''[[The Daily Show]]'' on August 9, 2006. On March 12, 2007, he was promoted to a regular [[List of The Daily Show correspondents|correspondent]].<ref>{{cite press release|title=COMEDY CENTRAL'S 'THE DAILY SHOW WITH JON STEWART' TAPS AASIF MANDVI TO JOIN THE 'DAILY SHOW' NEWS TEAM AS A CORRESPONDENT |url=http://www.comedycentral.com/press/press_releases/2007/31207_aasif_mandvi_joins_tds.jhtml |date=March 12, 2007 |publisher=[[Comedy Central]] |accessdate=November 7, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102095837/http://www.comedycentral.com/press/press_releases/2007/31207_aasif_mandvi_joins_tds.jhtml |archivedate=January 2, 2008 }}</ref> He is the lead actor, co-writer and producer of the web series ''[[Halal in the Family]]'', which premiered on [[Funny or Die]] in 2015, and an actor, writer and co-producer of the [[HBO]] comedy series ''[[The Brink (TV series)|The Brink]]''. Mandvi is also the author of the book ''No Land's Man''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/1452107912/ |title=No Land's Man: Aasif Mandvi |publisher=[[Amazon.com]]}}</ref>
==Early life== Mandvi was born in Bombay (now [[Mumbai]]), [[Maharashtra]], [[India]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/2008/05/31005430/8216In-the-US-they-say-Ind.html|title='In the US, they say Indians are always laughing'|publisher=[[Livemint]]|date=May 31, 2008|author=Kilachand, Tara|accessdate=November 7, 2008}}</ref> to a [[Dawoodi Bohra]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtviggy.com/interviews/interview-with-the-last-airbender%E2%80%99s-aasif-mandvi-part-ii/|title='Interview with The Last Airbender's Aasif Mandvi: Part II'}}</ref> [[Muslim]] family.<ref name="tampa"/> His family moved to England, settling, when he was a year old, in the [[West Yorkshire]] city of [[Bradford]], where his father, Hakim, had originally come to work in textiles research at [[Bradford University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/player/v2/mediaPlayer.html?action=1&t=1&islist=false&id=361026157&m=361190374|title=NPR Media Player|work=npr.org|accessdate=September 2, 2015}}</ref> and later ran a [[corner shop]], while his mother, Fatima, was a nurse.<ref name="Guardian20090607">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jun/08/aasif-mandvi-tv-daily-show-usa|title='I get to sit on the fence between cultures': Sarfraz Manzoor talks to Aasif Mandvi, the Daily Show's 'fake news' correspondent|author=Sarfraz Manzoor|date=June 7, 2009|work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Deggans|first1=Eric|title=For Aasif Mandvi, cultural irreverence on 'The Daily Show'|url=http://www.tampabay.com/features/media/for-aasif-mandvi-cultural-irreverence-on-the-daily-show/545843|accessdate=28 June 2014|work=[[Tampa Bay Times]]|date=31 May 2008}}</ref> Although Mandvi identifies himself as a "working-class kid from Bradford", he attended the independent [[Woodhouse Grove School]].<ref name="Guardian20090607"/> His father grew frustrated with [[Margaret Thatcher]]'s Britain and moved his family to [[Tampa, Florida]] when Mandvi was 16.<ref name="Guardian20090607"/>
==Career==
===Early=== After graduating from the [[University of South Florida]] with a degree in Theatre,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0541902/bio#trivia|title='Asif Mandvi – Biography'|publisher=[[IMDB]]|date=December 7, 2011}}</ref> Mandvi worked as a performer at [[Disney's Hollywood Studios|Disney-MGM Studios]] at [[Walt Disney World Resort]].<ref name="tampa"/> He later moved to New York City, where he began appearing in [[off-Broadway]] productions. During this time, he was active in the band Cowboys and Indian. He won an [[Obie Award]] for his critically acclaimed one-man show ''Sakina's Restaurant''.<ref name="filmmaker">{{cite web|url=http://www.filmmakermagazine.com/summer2008/25faces_5.php|title=25 NEW FACES OF INDEPENDENT FILM|publisher=''[[Filmmaker Magazine]]''|year=2008 |accessdate=November 7, 2008}}</ref>
On Broadway, Mandvi appeared as Ali Hakim in the 2002 production of ''[[Oklahoma!]]'' directed by [[Trevor Nunn]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/services/amusement-recreation-services/4566365-1.html|title=Aasif Mandvi: Giving Broadway a Persian Hello|publisher=''[[Backstage (magazine)|Backstage]]''|date=March 29, 2002|author=Horwitz, Simi|accessdate=November 7, 2008}}</ref> He also appeared in the play ''Homebody/Kabul'' by [[Tony Kushner]]. He portrayed [[Fritz Haber]] in the [[off-Broadway]] play ''[[Einstein's Gift]]''.
Mandvi played Melchior in ''[[On the Razzle (play)|On the Razzle]]'' by [[Tom Stoppard]] at the [[Williamstown Theatre Festival]] and appeared in the docudrama ''[[Guantanamo: Honor Bound to Defend Freedom]]'' at the Culture Project. In 2012 Mandvi starred in ''[[Disgraced]]'' at [[Lincoln Center]]'s [[Claire Tow Theater]]. He played the lead role of Amir, a Pakistani American lawyer struggling with his identity and Islam in the drama by [[Ayad Akhtar]]. The play went on to win the 2013 [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Ayad Akhtar's 'Disgraced,' play about a dinner party gone awry, wins Pulitzer Prize for drama|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/theater_dance/ayad-akhtars-disgraced-wins-pulitzer-prize-for-drama/2013/04/15/defd1e6c-a5ff-11e2-9e1c-bb0fb0c2edd9_story.html |newspaper=Washington Post|date=April 16, 2013|author=Associated Press}}</ref> Mandvi was nominated for a [[Lucille Lortel Award]] for his role.
===Television=== Mandvi made his television debut as a doorman at the [[Miami Biltmore Hotel]] in the episode "Line of Fire" of the series ''[[Miami Vice]]''. He has since appeared in numerous television shows including ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', ''[[The Sopranos]]'', ''[[Sex and the City]]'', ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation|CSI]]'', ''[[Oz (TV series)|Oz]]'', ''[[Ed (TV series)|Ed]]'', ''[[The Bedford Diaries]]'', ''[[Jericho (2006 TV series)|Jericho]]'', ''[[Sleeper Cell (TV series)|Sleeper Cell]]'' and various editions of ''[[Law & Order]]'', including ''[[Law & Order: Criminal Intent|Criminal Intent]]'', ''[[Law & Order: SVU|Special Victims Unit]]'' and ''[[Law & Order: Trial by Jury|Trial by Jury]]''. He was the book reader for audio editions of [[Salman Rushdie]]'s ''[[Shalimar the Clown]]'' (2005) and [[V. S. Naipaul]]'s ''[[Magic Seeds]]'' (2004). In 2011 he appeared in [[Taco Bell]] commercials.
In 2006, Mandvi auditioned for ''[[The Daily Show]]''. He was hired immediately and appeared on the show the same day.<ref name="tampa"/> Mandvi became a regular correspondent in 2007. He often appears in segments satirizing and commenting on Islamic, Middle-Eastern, and South-Asian-related issues with such titles as "Senior Asian Correspondent," "Senior Middle East Correspondent," "Senior Foreign Looking Correspondent," and "Senior Muslim Correspondent."
In 2013, Mandvi was cast in a recurring role on the [[FOX]] romantic comedy, ''[[Us & Them]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|title=Aasif Mandvi & Michael Ian Black Join New Fox Series 'Us & Them'|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/08/aasif-mandvi-michael-ian-black-join-new-fox-series-us-them/|publisher=Deadline|accessdate=August 28, 2013}}</ref>
In October 2013, during a segment on ''The Daily Show'', Mandvi's interview with Don Yelton led to Yelton's resignation from the North Carolina Republican Party office.<ref>{{cite web|title=GOP’s Don Yelton Resigns After ‘Lazy Blacks’ Remark on ‘Daily Show’|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/BL-SEB-77898}}</ref>
In November 2014, he appeared on ''[[The Dan Patrick Show]]''. On the show, he revealed the story from his book ''No Land's Man'' where his father moved his family to the U.S. because the U.S. has brunch.<ref>{{YouTube|id=QdxeRfnymgI|title=Aasif Mandvi on The Dan Patrick Show (Full Interview) 11/14/2014}}</ref>
Beginning in June 2015, Mandvi portrayed Rafiq Massoud in the [[HBO]] comedy series ''[[The Brink (TV series)|The Brink]]''. Mandvi also serves as a writer and co-producer on the series.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2015/06/21/why-aasif-mandvi-never-wanted-to-fill-jon-stewarts-shoes/|title=Why Aasif Mandvi never wanted to fill Jon Stewart’s shoes - New York Post|work=New York Post|accessdate=September 2, 2015}}</ref> In April 2015, Mandvi appeared on ''[[Person of Interest (TV series)|Person of Interest]]'' as Sulaiman Khan, the CEO of a software security firm.
In 2016, Mandvi joined the climate change documentary show ''[[Years of Living Dangerously]]'' as one of its celebrity correspondents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvblogs.nationalgeographic.com/2015/09/17/critically-acclaimed-climate-change-series-years-of-living-dangerously-comes-to-nat-geo/ |title=Critically Acclaimed Climate Change Series "Years of Living Dangerously" Comes to Nat Geo |accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref>
In 2017, Mandvi guest-starred in two episodes of the first season of the Netflix series ''[[A Series of Unfortunate Events (TV series)|A Series of Unfortunate Events]]'' as Montgomery "Uncle Monty" Montgomery,<ref name="Mandvi">{{cite web|last1=Andreeva|first1=Nellie|title=Aasif Mandvi Cast In Netflix’s ‘A Series Of Unfortunate Events’ & USA’s ‘Mr. Robot’|url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/aasif-mandvi-cast-a-series-of-unfortunate-events-mr-robot-1201722925/|website=deadline.com|publisher=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=15 February 2017}}</ref> a [[herpetologist]] and distant relative of the Baudelaire children. He returned to the role for one episode during season two.
===Film=== Mandvi played minor roles in the films ''[[The Siege (1998 film)|The Siege]]'' and ''[[Die Hard with a Vengeance]]'' as well as the title role in [[Merchant Ivory Productions]]' film ''[[The Mystic Masseur]]''. He had a major supporting role in the independent film ''[[American Chai]]'', playing the lead character's roommate, "Engineering Sam." He played the doctor who diagnosed Paul Vitti's ([[Robert De Niro]]) panic attacks in ''[[Analyze This]],'' and had a role as Mr. Aziz of "Joe's Pizza" in ''[[Spider-Man 2]].'' He was also in commercials by [[Domino's Pizza]] and the [[Financial Industry Regulatory Authority]] (FINRA). He played the [[Tone deafness|tone deaf]] doorman Khan in ''[[Music and Lyrics]]''.
Mandvi played a dentist alongside [[Ricky Gervais]] in the 2008 romantic comedy ''[[Ghost Town (2008 film)|Ghost Town]]'', as well as office employee Bob Spaulding in ''[[The Proposal (film)|The Proposal]]'', starring [[Sandra Bullock]]. ''[[Today's Special (2009 film)|Today's Special]]'', which Mandvi co-wrote with Jonathan Bines, premiered at the [[London Film Festival]] in October 2009 and New York's [[Indo-American Arts Council|Mahindra Indo-American Arts Council Film Festival]] on November 11, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/priyanka-boghani/new-york-citys-indian-fil_b_356308.html|title=New York City's Indian Film Festival: MIAAC|author=Priyanka Boghani|date= November 12, 2009|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=November 10, 2009}}</ref> He appeared in ''[[It's Kind of a Funny Story (film)|It's Kind of a Funny Story]]'', a coming-of-age film written and directed by [[Anna Boden]] with [[Ryan Fleck]], adapted from the 2006 novel by [[Ned Vizzini]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Ryan Fleck's It's Kind of a Funny Story Begins Production |first=Peter |last=Sciretta |url=http://www.slashfilm.com/2009/11/30/ryan-flecks-its-kind-of-a-funny-story-begins-production |work= |date=November 30, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qQBRv9ri?url=http://www.slashfilm.com/2009/11/30/ryan-flecks-its-kind-of-a-funny-story-begins-production/ |archivedate=June 12, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> He also co-starred as a [[Guantanamo captive]] in the film ''[[The Response (film)|The Response]]'', a script based on the transcripts of [[Combatant Status Review Tribunal]]s convened in [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp|Guantanamo]] in 2004.<ref name=MLiveMandviGuantanamo> {{cite news | url=http://www.mlive.com/us-politics/index.ssf/2009/05/new_role_for_daily_show_report.html | title=New role for 'Daily Show' reporter | date=May 9, 2009 | author= | publisher=[[MLive]] | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mlive.com%2Fus-politics%2Findex.ssf%2F2009%2F05%2Fnew_role_for_daily_show_report.html&date=2009-09-05 | archivedate=September 5, 2009 }}</ref> In [[M. Night Shyamalan]]'s ''[[The Last Airbender]]'' (released in 2010) he played a major role as [[Admiral Zhao#Major recurring characters|Commander Zhao]]. Mandvi played the role of Mr. Chetty in the 2013 comedy ''[[The Internship]]'', which starred [[Vince Vaughn]] and [[Owen Wilson]] and portrayed [[Ash Vasudevan]] in the 2014 film ''[[Million Dollar Arm]]''.
==Charity work== Mandvi is involved with disaster-relief organizations such as the charity initiative Relief 4 Pakistan, which assists in flood relief in Pakistan. In 2010, he hosted the "Stand Up for Religious Freedom" comedy event to raise money for the organization.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fuerstenberg|first=Brittany|title=Aasif Mandvi: Comic Relief for Pakistan|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39832619/ns/us_news-giving/t/aasif-mandvi-comic-relief-pakistan/|accessdate=September 26, 2011|newspaper=MSNBC}}</ref> After the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]], he performed with fellow ''Daily Show'' correspondent [[Wyatt Cenac]] at [[Conan O'Brien]]'s "I'm with Coco" Benefit for earthquake victims. He is also a supporter of the Endometriosis Foundation of America.
